Subscribers onlyJapan braces up for another unprecedented Covid-19 wave

Monkeypox: Why are gay and bisexual men more affected?  The French public health agency has counted 1,567 cases in the country since May, with 3% requiring hospitalization. No deaths have been recorded in Europe, but the disease is on the rise.

Biden back in isolation in rare case of Covid-19 rebound  President Joe Biden tested positive for Covid-19 again on Saturday, slightly more than three days after he was cleared to exit coronavirus isolation.

Women's Tour de France: Jeannie Longo, a champion with no legacy  Despite having one of the most successful cycling careers, the former racer did not contribute to the development of the sport in France. Her exacerbated individualism could be to blame, but not exclusively.

Background   Corine Lesnes Subscribers onlyUS: how a pro-choice group made a fortune with a Republican politician's misogyny At a rally in Florida, pro-Trump Congressman Matt Gaetz made fatphobic remarks targeted at pro-choice activist Olivia Julianna. In response, her association 'Gen Z for change' raised more than two million dollars for the defense of abortion rights.   3 min read

Long Read   Simon Kuper Subscribers only'France and Britain have divided up the core competences of football: you are world champions on the field, we are in the stands' 'The UK, France and me' (6/6). British journalist and writer Simon Kuper, who left London for Paris 20 years ago, argues that France's world-beating football team is wasted on its fans, whereas British fans don't even need a victory to celebrate their teams.   6 min read

Long Read   Benoît Hopquin Subscribers only'I felt guilty about coming back': Life after the Vél' d'Hiv Roundup On July 16 and 17, 1942, in Paris, the French police organized the largest-ever roundup of Jewish women, men and children, before sending them to the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp.   16 min read

Investigation   Aureliano Tonet and  Laurent Carpentier Subscribers onlyMK2, Mediapro, Feltrinelli: European cultural giants born from the far left A Trotskyist in Barcelona, a Maoist in Paris and a Guevarist in Milan: It was from the sidelines that Jaume Roures, Marin Karmitz and Carlo Feltrinelli understood capitalism, and it was by starting revolutions that they built their cultural empires.   15 min read
